docs.lead_paragraph: ABRAMS--Jerome, MD, died peacefully after a distinguished career in Obstetrics and Gynecology in the Plainfields and Fanwood, NJ. Born in Plainfield to Leah Cantor Abrams and Hyman Abrams, he served as an Ensign in the Pacific during WWII. After graduating from Swarthmore, he obtained an MA in History from Columbia University and completed his MD and residency at Jefferson. He published numerous articles in the field of Ob-Gyn, was an associate editor of the New Jersey Medical Journal, and a Clinical Professor at Rutgers Medical School. Later in his career he obtained a Masters of Public Health from Rutgers University. Passionate about opera and history, in the early 1960's he was published in the Metropolitan Opera News. After retirement he was a frequent lecturer at Rutgers Institute for Lifelong Learning in the fields of History, Political Science and Medicine. A gentleman, scholar, and renaissance man, he was kind and loving to his wife Rosalyn Yaskin, his sons Alan (Cheryl) of Villanova, PA, Joseph (Marie) of Rye, NY, his grandchildren Harrison, Emilie, Thomas, and Jonathan, and his brother Herbert Abrams (Joan) of Brookline MA. Donations in his name to the Center for Hope Hospice of Scotch Plains, NJ or the Parkinson's Disease Foundation would be appreciated.

docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists have discovered gene mutations that give people naturally lower cholesterol levels and cut their risk of heart disease in half.

headline.main: Gene Study Boosts Interest in Heart Drug Zetia
headline.print_headline: Gene Study Boosts Interest in Heart Drug Zetia

docs.snippet: Scientists have discovered gene mutations that give people naturally lower cholesterol levels and cut their risk of heart disease in half.

headline.main: Website Explores Sugar's Effects on Health

docs.abstract: SugarScience.org, a new website, seeks to educate the public on how too much sugar makes people sick.
docs.snippet: SugarScience.org, a new website, seeks to educate the public on how too much sugar makes people sick.

docs.lead_paragraph: The body of knowledge about how the brain works is growing, but so is the list of gaps in our understanding. Larry Abbott, a former theoretical physicist, is looking for models to fill them in.

headline.main: Learning How Little We Know About the Brain

docs.abstract: Research on brain is surging, but growing body of data represents paradox of progress, with advances also highlighting great gaps in understanding; scientists, who speculate on grand scale but work on limited scale, are struggling to resolve both large and small questions.
docs.snippet: The body of knowledge about how the brain works is growing, but so is the list of gaps in our understanding. Larry Abbott, a former theoretical physicist, is looking for models to fill them in.
